titlestmt.titleproper: Register of the Russia. Posol'stvo (France) Records, 1916-1924
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Ronald Bulatoff and Paul Karpuk; machine-readable finding aid created by Xiuzhi Zhou

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2016-09-07T09:11-0700

did.abstract: Correspondence, reports, memoranda, and notes, relating to relations between France and the Russian Provisional Government, the Russian Revolution, counter-revolutionary movements, the Paris Peace Conference, and Russian emigres after the revolution. Entire collection also on microfilm (38 reels).

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p:
The collection is open for research.
The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Russia. Posol'stvo (France) Records, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 1926.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The files of the Russian Embassy in Paris at the Hoover Institution cover the period of the ambassadorship of Basil Maklakoff. Maklakoff was appointed ambassador of the Russian Provisional Government to France by Alexander Kerensky in March 1917, and remained as the Russian ambassador until France recognized the U.S.S.R. in 1926. The bulk of the records is dated from 1918 until 1922 and document the operations of White Russian forces in their five-year struggle against the Bolsheviks. Activities of the Russian Embassy in Paris included participation in the Paris Peace Conference, 1919, and the organization of network of social welfare offices for the Russian immigrants, military and civilian, who fled Russia during the Russian Civil War.
The Hoover Institution also is in possession of the personal papers of Basil Maklakoff, 1917-1957, which document his activities after the recognition of the U.S.S.R. by France.
